content.title: Lumbar Puncture
content.summary: Invasive procedure to obtain cerebrospinal fluid for diagnostic purposes or therapeutic drainage, performed by inserting a needle into the lumbar subarachnoid space
key_points: Access CSF from lumbar subarachnoid space (L3-L4 or L4-L5)
Indications: meningitis, SAH, MS, pseudotumor cerebri, Guillain-Barre
Check for papilledema/mass lesion before LP (risk of herniation)
Complications: post-LP headache, bleeding, infection, herniation

statement.text: Invasive procedure to obtain cerebrospinal fluid for diagnostic purposes or therapeutic drainage, performed by inserting a needle into the lumbar subarachnoid space
statement.formal: Lumbar Puncture = Clinical presentation + Diagnosis + Treatment

explanation.intuition: Understanding Lumbar Puncture is essential for clinical practice.
explanation.key_insight: Key concepts in Lumbar Puncture management.
explanation.technical_details: Needle inserted between lumbar vertebrae into subarachnoid space where CSF circulates. CSF is produced in choroid plexus and circulates around brain and spinal cord. Analysis includes cell count, protein, glucose, culture, and special studies.

pathophysiology.mechanism: Needle inserted between lumbar vertebrae into subarachnoid space where CSF circulates. CSF is produced in choroid plexus and circulates around brain and spinal cord. Analysis includes cell count, protein, glucose, culture, and special studies.
etiologies: Diagnostic: meningitis/encephalitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, demyelinating disease, normal pressure hydrocephalus

contraindications.absolute: Skin infection at site, evidence of herniation

technique.opening_pressure: Measure in lateral decubitus (normal 6-20 cm H2O)

treatment_options.post_lp_headache: Occurs in 10-30%; treat with rest, caffeine, blood patch if severe
treatment_options.csf_analysis: Cell count, protein, glucose, gram stain/culture, cytology, oligoclonal bands as indicated
